manual: Elements of Science and Art. Vol. 2
name: cement for fixing…stones
description: Resin, pitch and beeswax. Add powdered marble or freestone and a little sulphur
source: IMISON, John.: Elements of Science and Art. being a familiar introduction to natural philosophy and chemistry; together with their application to a variety of elegant and useful arts (in two Volumes), Vol.2. First edition 1788. Published by the University of California. 1822.

manual: Der wohl anführende Mahler.
name: Stein- und Holz Kitt
description: Wachs 1 loth, Pech 2 l., Schwefel 2l. Ziegel-Mehl 1 l., Kalk 1 l., L(ein)Öl 1 l.
source: CRÖKER, Johann Melchior Der wohl anführende Mahler. Jena. 1736. München, Bayerische Staatsbibliothek, Art. 463 i

manual: Der wohl anführende Mahler.
name: Ein Stein-Leim

ingredients.amount: so viel als wie ein Eh groß ist

description: Harz 1 pfund, Schwefel 8 loth, Pech (so viel als ein Eh groß ist), Hammerschlag 2 Hände voll, Steinstaub (ebenso), Wachs (soviel wie Pech) = 1:1
source: CRÖKER, Johann Melchior Der wohl anführende Mahler. Jena. 1736. München, Bayerische Staatsbibliothek, Art. 463 i

manual: Der wohl anführende Mahler.
name: oder (s. ein Stein-Leim)
description: Pech, Kreide, Bleiweiß und Wachs
source: CRÖKER, Johann Melchior Der wohl anführende Mahler. Jena. 1736. München, Bayerische Staatsbibliothek, Art. 463 i

manual: Hand- und Hülfsbuch für alle Künstler und Handwerker…
name: Der Loßius'sche verbesserte Steinkitt oder sogenannte Feuerkitt
description: §.83 Der Loßius'sche verbesserte Steinkitt oder sogenannte Feuerkittbesteht aus 24 Loth Kollophonium oder Pech, 3 loth gelben Wachs, 2 Loth Terpentin, 1 loth gestossenen Mastix, 1 loth schwefel und einer handvoll Ziegelmehl. Diese Masse wird in einem eisernen Topfe am Feuer zerlassen, und fleißig umf´gerührt. Wenn deser Kitt gebraucht werden soll, so müssen die Fugen mit glühenden Holzkohlen oder aber mit einem glühenden Eisen heiß gemacht werden, und so wird auch die Masse heiß eingegossen. - Dieser Kitt, wen man ihn be platt liegenden Steinen, oder auch sonst bei eisernen Platten wohl anwendet, wird gleich hart, so daß das überstehende weggemeißelt wedren muss. Von diesem Ferkitt kann man sich auf viele Jahre Vorat machen, ihn in Stücken aufheben und bei Gebrauch so viel abschlagen und schmelzen, als man eben nöthig hat.
source: GÜTLE, J. C.: Hand- und Hülfsbuch für alle Künstler und Handwerker, die Kitte, Formen und Massen zugebrauchen: oder eine Auswahl von 600 verschiedenen Recepten, alle Arten Kitte, Leime, Formen und Massenzu verfertigen. Nürnberg. 1812

manual: Building in England down to 1540. A documentary history
name: requirements for the cistern in the King’s court at Westminster
description: 19 lb. of pitch and 5 lb of wax, bought for 14 s. [shilling]; and 7d. [pence] was paid ‘for charcoal for cementing the cistern’
source: SALZMANN, Louis Francis: Building in England down to 1540. A documentary history. Oxford University Press. 1952. Reissued 1992. Special edition for Sandpiper Books 1997.

manual: Building in England down to 1540. A documentary history
name: repairs to a buttress of Westminster palace (which projected into the Thames)
description:
For 60 lbs. of pitch for making cement (symento) for the buttress – 3s. 
 For 100 Flemish tiles for making dust for the same cement – 12d. 
 For three earthen pans (patellis) in which to make cement – 6d. 
 For straw bought for the same buttress, to burn upon it and warm it after the Thames flood (inundaciones), because the stone could not otherwise have held the cement -7d. 
 For an iron for directing (addressandum) and pouring cement between the stones – 4d.
source: SALZMANN, Louis Francis: Building in England down to 1540. A documentary history. Oxford University Press. 1952. Reissued 1992. Special edition for Sandpiper Books 1997.

manual: Building in England down to 1540. A documentary history
name: the Tower, repair of the foundations of the turret beside the Thames opposite to the King’s Exchange’
description:
for an iron pan in which to heat cement (cemento) for mending the said foundation, holding 2 gallons –6s. 
 Also for a cauldron (cacabo) bound with iron, in which to make cement, holding 3 gallons -20d. 
 For an iron ladel (?) and an iron slice (?), with a tripod, to serve the masons making cement -2s. 
 6d…for straw to warm the stones for the repair and mending of the foundation of the turret -18d. … 
 For tylpoudre [tile-powder] for making cement for the foundations of the turret -18d. 
 For 75 lbs. of pitch for making cement -6s. 3d. 
 For a bushel (~40 liters) of tyldust [tile-dust] for the same -18d. 
 For straw to warm the stones for the said foundation – 8d. … 
 For 2 lbs of rosyn, of which to make cement -4d.
source: SALZMANN, Louis Francis: Building in England down to 1540. A documentary history. Oxford University Press. 1952. Reissued 1992. Special edition for Sandpiper Books 1997.

manual: Building in England down to 1540. A documentary history
name: for the steyning of a well at Silverston
description:
6,5 lb. wax 
 4 stone of pitch 
 Sulphur to the value of 1,5 d. 
  A pennyworth of eggs 
 All said to be ‘for cement’ 
 And a payment of 8 d. for making the said cement
source: SALZMANN, Louis Francis: Building in England down to 1540. A documentary history. Oxford University Press. 1952. Reissued 1992. Special edition for Sandpiper Books 1997.

manual: Building in England down to 1540. A documentary history
name: for the steyning of a well at Silverston
description:
4 lb. of sulphur 
 1 lb. of wax, 
 4 lb. of resin 
 Used for cement
source: SALZMANN, Louis Francis: Building in England down to 1540. A documentary history. Oxford University Press. 1952. Reissued 1992. Special edition for Sandpiper Books 1997.

j lb. waxe (at 6d.) 
 ij lb. rosyn (at 1d.) 
 ‘for the masons to make thereof symon’

source: SALZMANN, Louis Francis: Building in England down to 1540. A documentary history. Oxford University Press. 1952. Reissued 1992. Special edition for Sandpiper Books 1997.

manual: The city and country purchaser's and builder's dictionary: or, the complete builder's guide.
name: To make hot Cement.
description:
Take one Pound of Rosin, and a Quarter of a Pound of Bees-wax, halt an Ounce of fine Brickdust, half an Ounce of Chalkdust, or Powder of Chalk ; sift both the Brickdust and Chalk-dust thro' a fine Hair Sieve (you may beat the Brick and the Chalk in a Mortar, before you sift it) boil all together in a Pipkin, about a quarter of an Hour, stirring it all the while with an Iron, or a Piece of Lath, or such like; then take it off, and let it stand 4 or five Minutes, and it is fit for Use. 
 Note, The Bricks to be cemented with this kind of Cement, must be made hot by the Fire before you spread the Cement on them, and then rub them to and fro, one upon another, as Joiners do, when they glew two Boards together.
source: NEVE, Richard: The city and country purchaser's and builder's dictionary: or, the complete builder's guide. ... Originally written and compiled by Richard Neve, Philomath. The third edition, corrected and improved throughout. 1736

manual: The craftsman's handbook : the Italian 'Il libro dell'arte'
name: How you should make cement for mending stones – Chapter CVI
description: There is a cement which is good for mending stones: and this one is made of mastic, fresh wax, sifted pounded stone; and then all melted up thoroughly together on the fire. Take your broken stone, and warm it well; put some of this cement on it. It will last forever, in the wind; and in water if you were to mend sharpening or grinding wheels, or millstones, with it.
source: THOMPSON, Daniel V. Jr. The craftsman's handbook : the Italian 'Il libro dell'arte' / Cennino d'Andrea Cennini ; translated by Daniel V. Thompson, Jr. New York. Dover. 2005

manual: Istruzione elementare per gli studiosi della scultura
name: About restoring ancient sculptures
description: But for greater security, a mixture of Greek pitch is made, clear and clean, which is put to simmer on the fire, and in which, when it is thick and boiling, add/add(?) finely ground marble powder, passed through a silk veil or taffeta sieve, stirring it all at the same time with a wooden stick, to the point of making a thick glue. This is kept warm, while both parts to be joined together, as well as the pivot, are heated with burning coals. Then, leaving a wet slab above, pour a little of the warm mixture to make two small lumps to be placed inside the holes where the pivot is to go. Then both the joints of the parts are greased with the same tender mixture, which must first be marked, and then with skill, when they are very hot, they are applied diligently in place, trying to cool the pieces as quickly as possible with water and a sponge, always supporting them in the same place until, when the mixture has set, they can no longer move.
source: CARRADORI, Francesco: Istruzione elementare per gli studiosi della scultura, Firenze, 1802
